problem_text:
b) A formation F of finite groups is called superradical if it is Sn-closed and contains every finite group of the form G = AB where A and B are F-subnormal F-subgroups. Prove that every S-closed superradical formation is a solubly saturated formation.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: b) A counterexample is constructed (S. Yi, S. F. Kamornikov, Siberian Math. J., 57, no. 2 (2016), 260–264).
